title: The Complexity of Finding Fair Independent Sets in Cycles

sections.introduction:
In 1986, Du, Hsu, and HwangÂ  conjectured that if a graph on 3â€‹n3ğ‘›3n vertices is the disjoint union of a Hamilton cycle of length 3â€‹n3ğ‘›3n and nğ‘›n pairwise vertex-disjoint triangles then its independence number is nğ‘›n.
The conjecture has become known as the â€˜cycle plus trianglesâ€™ problem and has been strengthened by ErdÃ¶sÂ 2, who conjectured that such a graph is 333-colorable.
Fleischner and StiebitzÂ  confirmed these conjectures in a strong form and proved, using an algebraic approach of Alon and TarsiÂ , that such a graph is in fact 333-choosable.
Their proof can also be viewed as an application of Alonâ€™s Combinatorial Nullstellensatz techniqueÂ . Slightly later, an alternative elementary proof of the 333-coloring result was given by SachsÂ 4. However, none of these proofs supplies an efficient algorithm that given a graph on 3â€‹n3ğ‘›3n vertices whose set of edges is the disjoint union of a Hamilton cycle and nğ‘›n pairwise vertex-disjoint triangles finds a 333-coloring of the graph or an independent set of size nğ‘›n. Questions on the computational aspects of the problem were posed in several works over the years (see, e.g.,Â    ). A natural extension of the problem of Du et al.Â  is the following. Let GğºG be a cycle and let V1,â€¦,Vmsubscriptğ‘‰1â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘šV_{1},\ldots,V_{m} be a partition of its vertex set into mğ‘šm sets.
We are interested in an independent set of GğºG that (almost) fairly represents the given partition, that is, an independent set Sğ‘†S of GğºG satisfying |Sâˆ©Vi|â‰¥12â‹…|Vi|âˆ’1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–â‹…12subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1|S\cap V_{i}|\geq\frac{1}{2}\cdot|V_{i}|-1 for all iâˆˆ[m]={1,â€¦,m}ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘š1â€¦ğ‘ši\in[m]=\{1,\ldots,m\}. The existence of such an independent set was proved in a work of Aharoni, Alon, Berger, Chudnovsky, Kotlar, Loebl, and ZivÂ . For the special case where all the sets Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} are of size 333, the proof technique of Aharoni et al.Â  allowed them to show that there are two disjoint independent sets that fairly represent the partition, providing a new proof of a stronger form of the original conjecture of Du et al.Â . The results ofÂ  were then extended in a work of Alishahi and MeunierÂ . A special case of one of their results is the following. Let GğºG be a cycle on nğ‘›n vertices and let V1,â€¦,Vmsubscriptğ‘‰1â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘šV_{1},\ldots,V_{m} be a partition of its vertex set into mğ‘šm sets.
Suppose that nğ‘›n and mğ‘šm have the same parity.
Then, there exist two disjoint independent sets S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2} of GğºG covering all vertices but one from each Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} such that for each jâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘—12j\in\{1,2\}, it holds that |Sjâˆ©Vi|â‰¥12â‹…|Vi|âˆ’1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–â‹…12subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1|S_{j}\cap V_{i}|\geq\frac{1}{2}\cdot|V_{i}|-1 for all iâˆˆ[m]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ši\in[m]. As shown by Black et al.Â 0, analogues of TheoremÂ 1.1 for paths and for partitions into sets of odd sizes can also be proved using the approach of Aharoni et al.Â . It is interesting to mention that although the statements of TheoremÂ 1.1 and of its aforementioned variants are purely combinatorial, all of their known proofs are based on tools from topology. The use of topological methods in combinatorics was initiated by LovÃ¡szÂ 6 who applied the Borsuk-Ulam theoremÂ 1 from algebraic topology to prove a conjecture of KneserÂ 5 on the chromatic number of Kneser graphs. For integers nâ‰¥2â€‹kğ‘›2ğ‘˜n\geq 2k, the Kneser graph Kâ€‹(n,k)ğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘˜K(n,k) is the graph whose vertices are all the kğ‘˜k-subsets of [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n] where two sets are adjacent if they are disjoint. It was proved inÂ 6 that the chromatic number of Kâ€‹(n,k)ğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘˜K(n,k) is nâˆ’2â€‹k+2ğ‘›2ğ‘˜2n-2k+2, a result that was strengthened and generalized by several researchers (see, e.g.,Â [39, ChapterÂ 3]).
One such strengthening was obtained by SchrijverÂ 6, who studied the subgraph of Kâ€‹(n,k)ğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘˜K(n,k) induced by the collection of all kğ‘˜k-subsets of [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n] with no two consecutive elements modulo nğ‘›n. This graph is denoted by Sâ€‹(n,k)ğ‘†ğ‘›ğ‘˜S(n,k) and is commonly referred to as the Schrijver graph. It was proved inÂ 6, again by a topological argument, that the chromatic number of Sâ€‹(n,k)ğ‘†ğ‘›ğ‘˜S(n,k) is equal to that of Kâ€‹(n,k)ğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘˜K(n,k).
As for TheoremÂ 1.1, the proof of Alishahi and MeunierÂ  employs the Octahedral Tucker lemma that was applied by MatouÅ¡ekÂ 8 in an alternative proof of Kneserâ€™s conjecture and can be viewed as a combinatorial formulation of the Borsuk-Ulam theorem (see alsoÂ 8). The approach of Aharoni et al.Â  and of Black et al.Â 0, however, is based on a direct application of the chromatic number of the Schrijver graph.
As before, these proofs are not constructive, in the sense that they do not suggest efficient algorithms for the corresponding search problems.
Understanding the computational complexity of these problems is the main motivation for the current work. In 1994, PapadimitriouÂ 3 has initiated the study of the complexity of total search problems in view of the mathematical argument that lies at the existence proof of their solutions.
Let ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{TFNP} be the complexity class, defined inÂ 0, of the total search problems in ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}, that is, the class of search problems in which a solution is guaranteed to exist and can be verified in polynomial running-time.
Papadimitriou has introduced inÂ 3 several subclasses of ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{TFNP}, each of which consists of the total search problems that can be reduced to a problem that represents some mathematical argument.
For example, the class ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA} (Polynomial Parity Argument) corresponds to the simple fact that every graph with maximum degree 222 that has a vertex of degree 111 must have another degree 111 vertex. Hence, ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA} is defined as the class of all problems in ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{TFNP} that can be efficiently reduced to the Leaf problem, in which given a succinct representation of a graph with maximum degree 222 and given a vertex of degree 111 in the graph, the goal is to find another such vertex.
The class ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{PPAD} (Polynomial Parity Argument in Directed graphs) is defined similarly with respect to directed graphs.
Another complexity class defined inÂ 3 is ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–¯\mathsf{PPP} (Polynomial Pigeonhole Principle) whose underlying mathematical argument is the pigeonhole principle. Additional examples of complexity classes defined in this way are ğ–¯ğ–«ğ–²ğ–¯ğ–«ğ–²\mathsf{PLS} (Polynomial Local Search)Â 4, ğ–¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–¢ğ–«ğ–²\mathsf{CLS} (Continuous Local Search)Â 5, and ğ–¤ğ–®ğ–¯ğ–«ğ–¤ğ–®ğ–¯ğ–«\mathsf{EOPL} (End of Potential Line)Â . The complexity class ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{PPAD} is known to perfectly capture the complexity of many important search problems.
Notable examples of ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{PPAD}-complete problems are those associated with Spernerâ€™s lemmaÂ 3 2, the Nash Equilibrium theoremÂ 3 4, the Envy-Free Cake Cutting theoremÂ , and the Hairy Ball theoremÂ 0.
For ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}, the undirected analogue of ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–£\mathsf{PPAD}, until recently no â€˜naturalâ€™ complete problems were known, where by â€˜naturalâ€™ we mean that their definitions do not involve circuits and Turing machines. In the last few years, the situation was changed following a breakthrough result of Filos-Ratsikas and GoldbergÂ  , who proved that the Consensus Halving problem with an inverse-polynomial precision parameter is ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-complete (see alsoÂ ) and used it to derive the ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-completeness of the classical Splitting Necklace with two thieves and Discrete Sandwich problems. This was obtained building on the ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-hardness, proved by Aisenberg, Bonet, and BussÂ , of the search problem associated with Tuckerâ€™s lemma. The variant of the problem that corresponds to the Octahedral Tucker lemma was suggested for study by PÃ¡lvÃ¶lgyiÂ 2 and proved to be ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-complete by Deng, Feng, and KulkarniÂ 9.
The ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-completeness of the Consensus Halving problem was improved to a constant precision parameter in a recent work of Deligkas, Fearnley, Hollender, and MelissourgosÂ 7.
Additional examples of ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ– \mathsf{PPA}-complete problems can be found, for instance, in the works of Belovs et al.Â , SchniderÂ 5, and Deligkas et al.Â 8.
